Award.AbstractNarration:
The Shanks Workshop on Geometric Analysis will take place in Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, from March 11-12, 2016. The workshop intends to bring together some leading researches in the area of geometric analysis, a field of research motivated by questions in both pure mathematics and the applied sciences. Geometric analysis is an area that requires tools from different mathematical fields, hence the importance of bringing together researchers with different backgrounds and similar research interests. One of the difficulties faced by researchers in the field is that many problems require a wide variety of geometric and analytic techniques. This often prevents researches working on similar problems from communicating with each other. This workshop will help overcoming such barriers, assuring that the vast amount of techniques available in the field are shared among its members, and giving incentives to researches to pursue future collaborations. It will also be an opportunity for graduate students to interact with leading researchers and be exposed to cutting-edge developments in the field.

The workshop will focus on problems that require a genuine interplay between methods from modern Riemannian geometry, partial differential equations, and, to a lesser extent, algebraic geometry and topology. It will involve topics such as recent developments in connection with the Yamabe problem and the Yamabe invariant of manifolds, extensions of classical results to manifolds with boundary, mathematical general relativity, recent developments in Kahler geometry, among others.

For more details, see the webpage: https://my.vanderbilt.edu/shanksgeomanalysis/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a two-day workshop which took place at Vanderbilt University from March 11 to March 12, 2016.The workshop had six speakers and seven participants from institutions other than Vanderbilt. Vanderbilt faculty and students also attended.

The Speakers were: Bianca Santoro (CUNY-City College of NY), Boris Botvinnik (University of Oregon), Jie Qing (University of California Santa Cruz), Ken Knox (University of Tennessee at Knoxville), Michael Anderson (Stony Brook University), Michael Lock (University of Texas Austin).

The non-Vanderbilt attendees were: Brian Allen (graduate student, University of Tennessee Knoxville),  Aaron Madewell (graduate student, Georgia State University), Mehrzad Monzavi (graduate student, University of Texas at Arlington), Greg Edwards (graduate student, Northwestern University), Brian Benson (post-doc, Kansas State University), Peng Yu (faculty, Westminster College), Mehdi Lejmi (faculty, Bronx Community College of CUNY).

Funding was provided by the Shanks Endowment ($4,000) and the NSF Award 1610645 ($12,000).The Shanks Endowment funding was used to cover the travel and lodging of the speakers; to pay for refreshments and the workshop reception; and to pay the two graduate students (Chang-Hsin Lee and Sahana Balasubramanya) who worked at preparing the refreshments.  NSF funds were used to support the workshop attendees, with preference given for graduate students and underrepresented minorities.

The talks were all of high quality and a wide variety of topics were covered, ranging from topological to analytic methods employed in the study of geometric problems. The workshop presented a valuable opportunity for students and young researchers to interact with some of the leading experts in the field of geometric analysis. It also created an avenue for the free exchange of mathematical ideas.

The attendees were almost unanimous in expressing their high degree of satisfaction with all aspects of the workshop, including the choice and quality of mathematical topics discussed, the workshop organization, and the amount of financial support provided.

More details of the workshop can be found on its webpage:

https://my.vanderbilt.edu/shanksgeomanalysis/

Of the total amount of of $12,000 provided by the NSF, $8,941.55 have been spent on participant's support. The organizers obtained NSF approval to use the remaining funds to support participants in the International Conference on Evolution Equations, that took place at Vanderbilt University on May 16-20, 2016. The funds were used to support participants presenting research results on topics aligned with the theme of the Shanks Workshop on Geometric Analysis. The participants supported were: Mihaela Ifrim (post-doc, University of California Berkeley), Leandro Lichtenfelz (graduate student, University of Notre Dame), Andrei Tarfulea (post-doc, University of Chicago), Xinliang An (post-doc, Rutgers University), Moritz Reintjes (post-doc, IMPA, Brazil).

Further information about the International Conference on Evolution Equations can be found on its webpage:

https://as.vanderbilt.edu/math/2016/05/international-conference-on-evolution-equations-may-16-20/
